column4: can anyone tell me the big difference between Ubuntu Desktop and Server editions ?

the server edition is optimized for server use, primarily intended not to be used with a graphical user interface, and it defaults to having very little software installed.  as a server admin, you'll generally know what you want, and you can manually install it.
Okay. thanks. here is my situation, I'm a relatively new linux user, but Ive dabbled with Ubuntu for a while now. I had a desktop install on a pc which I was primarily using remotely
I don't recommend you use a GUI on a server.  better to keep the resources free for actual serving.  the learning curve is steeper but it's manageable.  Desktop, different matter of course.
that makes sense. though, im running on a shoddy old Dell Dimension 8200
the shoddier, the more you don't want to run a GUI. :) my about-to-be-retired server was a modest PII-333 with 768 MB of RAM, but would have easily run ok with 256M of RAM.  no GUI though.
depends on what you want to do and how much traffic it will handle, of course.  but a modest machine can do a lot if you don't saddle it with handling a GUI.
you can, you need a boot CD/DVD to get it started, and it will install some packages off CD but the rest off the Internet.
by default? what about a via PXE? saves me downloading and burning a cd
I've never done an Ubuntu installation that way, so I really don't know.
unless you have a very slow Internet connection, I recommend you do the traditional installation.
dont you mean fast?
no, I said I recommend a standard CD-based installation, *unless* your Internet connection is very slow.
you can still download it on a slow connection.  but it will take a long time.  if your connection is that slow, best to order a CD, or have a friend burn you one.
I have a modest broadband connection and it only takes a few minutes for me to download an image.
ret some rewriteables, then you don't have to waste the disc.
I have booted off rewriteables many times.  just get good ones.  the best ones are the old, slow, 4x ones.  take longer to burn, but they tend to work a lot more reliably.
and you can still buy them.  some burners don't support any faster than 4x for rewriteables.
then you possibly have a bad burner.  CD-RWs should be useable a hundred times or more if you take care of them.
that's a software issue, or a burner issue.  there is nothing inherently different about burning a data CD-RW versus burning an .iso image to CD-RW.
yes, ext3 strongly recommended over ext2.  it runs well even on very old systems.  I have ext3 on a 486sx25..  not much of a noticeable difference in performance.
